To the most illustrious, high-born princes and lords, Lord Allbrecht, Margrave of Brandenburg, in Prussia etc., dukes etc.
Grace and peace from God our Father through Jesus Christ our Savior. Most illustrious and high-born prince, a short time ago a letter from Luther has been sent to your princely grace, in which he speaks out against those who are half-opposed to his teaching on the Lord's Supper, that they have nothing to do with them, not to let them go, since his teaching and articles are whole, clear, pure and undoubted and founded on the Gospel, so that no one may overturn them. But he does not give any grounds for this, but rather hastens to not only cruelly and shamefully slander us innocent ones, calling us to shed our blood (truly not from an apostolic spirit), but also to stir up and incite the natural meekness of those born in your princely realm against those of our opinion, to rage, to persecute them and to banish them from the land. And although we unanimously resolved to answer his book (since it is not worthy of it: it will also be shameful and hateful to all reasonable, wise and good-hearted people), he did not want to see this as good, to be completely silent, especially towards your princely realm, which he would like to annoy with such restlessness and clumsy writing (God forbid) and to stir up and incite the innocent pious ones.

Most high and noble prince, it is shortly reported that a letter from Luther has gone out, in which he commands Understadt, etc., that they have no dealings with those who are half-opposed to his doctrine of the Lord's Supper, but exile them from the land, since his doctrine and articles are whole, clear, pure and undivided, and founded on the Gospel, which no one can overthrow. Yet he shows no grounds for this, but rashly, not only cruelly and unjustly slanders us innocent ones, shedding our blood (which is certainly not from the spirit of the apostles), but also stirs up the Understadt natives' meekness to be angry against those in the princely state of our opinion, to rage, to persecute and exile them from the land. And although we unanimously resolved to answer him in his book (for it is not worth the trouble: it will also be ashamed before all reasonable, right-thinking and good-hearted people and be put to shame) yet we would not regard it as good to be completely silent, particularly against your highness, which he wants to trouble with such restlessness and unskilled writing (which God forbid) and to arouse and incite against the pious and innocent. Therefore, in this preface, we do not answer Luther (who has hardened his heart and is obliged by his confession to regard anything else as foolishness, and therefore does not hear us), but make a humble, submissive and warm plea to your highness, rejecting the shame and abusive words which Luther has not only directed at us, but also at the truth. Your highness, however, should mercifully spare us, hear our defense and patiently listen, so that we are not condemned and sentenced unjustly and unheard.

Peace and grace from God our Father through Jesus Christ our Saviour.Most high and noble prince, a letter has recently been sent to your highness from Luther which instructs that no consideration should be taken of those who are against his teachings on the Lord's Supper, and that they should be banished from the land. He claims that his teachings, along with his articles, are clear, pure and without doubt and are founded on the Gospel, so that no one can refute them. However, he does not provide any evidence to back up his claims, but instead, not only cruelly and mercilessly slaughters us innocent people (certainly not in the spirit of the apostles), but also attempts to stir up and provoke the born-again humility of those in your principality who are of our opinion, to rage against them, to threaten them and to banish them from the land. Even though we unanimously agreed not to respond to his book, because it is not worthy of it, and everyone of sound reason, right understanding and good heart would be ashamed of it and make it of no account, we did not consider it good to remain completely silent, especially in regard to your highness, since he has with such foolishness and inappropriate writing (may God forbid) stirred and provoked people against us innocent people of faith.
Therefore, we do not want to respond to Luther (who has hardened his heart and in his confession has pledged himself to consider as foolishness whatever else he may confess) in this preface, but rather humbly, sincerely and heartily want to make a plea to your highness, rejecting the shame and slander which Luther has not only cast upon us, but also upon the truth. May your highness graciously release us, hear our defense and patiently listen, so that we will not be condemned and sentenced unjustly and without a hearing. For it is not proper that Luther should be both accuser and judge, which he claims to be in his letter to your highness, since there is little truth and justification in the part where he is supposed to bring charges against us, and yet he brings the complaint sharply and the sentence cruelly against us.
We, however, have hitherto spared him in many ways (as all believers know) and have never wanted to counter his blasphemy and unseemly writings with equal measure; and to this day we still seek peace and unity with him (as far as this is possible in accordance with God and the truth). But above all else he slanders, defames, insults and maligns us, attacks us with disgraceful and dishonest names, calls us fanatics, rabble, heretics, devil's children and other words of shame, none of which he can ever prove with truth (may God forbid) for all eternity. It would be fitting, most high and noble prince and lord, that a teacher of truth, a servant of God, should do nothing but the work of his Lord, who has sent him, and that he should not soil the mouth, which God has prepared to proclaim His truth and word, with bitter false slander and libel, or with unfounded chatter and teaching, for such things are ill-suited to a messenger of God and of the truth.

seg.output: It is seen clearly and evidently from what has been learnt and discussed above that Luther's opinion has never been held as long as he has claimed and maintained, and that our true doctrine has never been rejected by the Church. The contrast is even more clear when it is seen that from the time of Jesus Christ and his apostles for many hundreds of years the Lord's Supper has been held by all believers, as we teach. And whenever this unfounded opinion has come up, there have always been pious learned and God-fearing men who have opposed it. And Luther cannot name a single teacher who was of his opinion, until Pope Innocent III, the third of that name, who drew up this article from the school of Paris and confirmed it at the Lateran Council. For he was also our master, and, in order to please his school, he raised this false and harmful opinion of the Church to the rank of an article of faith and thereby caused much harm to the Roman See, to which all the wealth of kings and princes was not enough. Moreover, Luther himself has not even written once that this article is the solid and powerful foundation of the papacy which must necessarily be overthrown if it is not based on Christ, the true cornerstone, or on his doctrine. And it is truly ridiculous and pitiful that Luther, such a learned man, should have taken such a heavy and great burden upon himself, that, even if he had nothing to do with his opinion, it would be enough for him that the Church had held it for so long. But what Church, O Luther? The Church of Christ? No, no, this will never be found to be true. The Church of the Pope? That is of no use to us, O Luther. Therefore, prince and lord, let us accept Luther's argument here that, as long as the papacy stands, it always relies on the Church and the length of time. But if all the doctrine of Luther were to be overthrown, it would be because he teaches something else than what the Roman Church has held for so many years.

seg.output: We being, then, in agreement with the Holy Church and with the truth and with the sincere understanding of divine scripture, never having been charged with error by divine scripture, and having never been refuted, how can we be condemned as heretics or schismatics?Truly, most illustrious prince and lord, Luther had no Christian love or compassion for us, nor did we find compassion and sympathy among our enemies.But is it not a cruel thing to give and surrender so many churches, in which are many thousands of devout believers, to the devil?Ulm, Memmingen, Eßlingen, Augsburg, Constance, Lindau, Zurich, Basel, Bern, Glarus, Soleure, Schaffhausen, Appenzell, Mülhausen, Biel, all three cantons, St. Gallen, the Rhine Valley, the Thurgau, Strasbourg and many other cities, lands, principalities, who are not affiliated with Luther in this article, who all thus surrender and reject arrogantly and give to the devil, not wanting to yield to the spirit of Christianity.And even though we may be divided and in error in external things, should we therefore give our weaker brethren to the devil?The gospel teaches this?Where has such a thing been heard from us against Luther and his followers?Although we have often maintained our opinion from the word of God with strong arguments of scripture, and will do so again where it is necessary.We can also point out his opinion contrary to scripture, yes, that it is contrary to the nature of faith, an abolishing and dissolution of the whole suffering and sacrifice of Christ on the cross.Yet neither we, nor those who are affiliated with us, have ever hereticated, ever given to the devil, ever called for expulsion or death.So when the apostles had the counsel of circumcision in Jerusalem, Peter gave a counsel closer to Christian freedom and truth, neither the counsel of James, nor do we say that, because of this, Peter rejected or so vilely despised James.Paul, the perfect man, did not despise the counsel of James, who gave something to the ceremonies, he was circumcised and regulated the faith, so that love would not be destroyed.And this perfect man was all things to all people for the sake of Christ.Can we then not be tolerated for the sake of Christian love, for the sake of peace and unity, since we have never been convicted or overcome by scripture?But is the devil our master, if we base ourselves on God's word alone?
